snippet: Three women who staged a protest against Vladimir V. Putin, Russia’s president, in a cathedral and became a cause célèbre of artists around the world were convicted of hooliganism.
abstract: Moscow judge sentences members of punk rock band Pussy Riot, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, Maria Alyokhina and Yekaterina, Samutsevich, to two years in a penal colony on charges of hooliganism; women had become an international cause celebre after they were arrested for staging an anti-Putin stunt in Moscow's main Orthodox cathedral.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Steven Lee Myers from Washington, and Nikolay Khalip, Anna Kordunsky, Ilya Mouzykantskii, Andrew Roth and Anna Tikhomirova from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: Three women who staged a protest against Vladimir V. Putin, Russia’s president, in a cathedral and became a cause célèbre of artists around the world were convicted of hooliganism.

headline.seo: Russian Punk Band Is Sentenced to 2 Years for Anti-Putin Protest
headline.main: Anti-Putin Stunt Earns Punk Band Two Years in Jail
headline.print_headline: Anti-Putin Stunt Earns Punk Band Two Years in Jail

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
